target_title: Update `watcher` on `pid-died` signal
Update `watcher` on `pid-died` signal

note.body:
Oh well. The particular case is a copy-paste mistake, unfortunately--it didn't have a `notify::` in my original testing--but seems like it "worked" simply because of a SEGFAULT (which closed the window w/o a prompt), meaning the whole MR is an inane result of my own deception.

Regardless of my efforts, the problem described is there anyway and needs to be fixed one way or another. I hope that, at the very least, this mishap has brought your attention to it.

cheers.

CPU usage

note.body: Apparently this is only available if the kernel was compiled with `CONFIG_PROC_CHILDREN=y`, but the code could actually test it and at least take the faster code path if it's available.

target_title: CPU usage

note.body: Rather than scanning the entire `/proc`, I believe you'd only have to look at `/proc/(the main shell's pid)/task/*/children`, that should be much cheaper. (At least on Linux, no idea about other Unices.)

target_title: CPU usage

note.body:
Running `strace -tt -f -o outputfile kgx` shows to me that it frequently scans all the processes under `/proc`, reads (and presuably parses) their `status` and `stat` files.

It's presumably for command completion notifications.

Sometimes it does this once every 2 seconds, sometimes twice every second. No clue why this difference.

Anyway, this could consume quite significant resources.

VTE, for the actual terminal emulation, surely uses some CPU too, it's not the cheapest across various terminal emulators I've tested; but it's not as expensive as Kgx, and it's at least completely idle if nothing happens in the terminal. It's been pointed out that Ptyxis, which uses the same VTE, also consumes less CPU. So there's definintely something here that Kgx itself adds to the game, and I highly suspect it's the scanning of `/proc` for detecting the running command.

target_title: Update `watcher` on `pid-died` signal

note.body: The same happens for command completion installers, e.g. from `glusterfs` (in `/etc/bash_completion.d/gluster.bash`): `pidof glusterfs`.

target_title: Window size is not remembered

note.body:
It is intentional that the window size is saved only when closing a window. One possible solution is that when opening a new window, the size is obtained from *another* open window if any, else use the setting. I find this a bit hacky though.

The maximized state could be saved whenever it is set as it is less expensive.

target_title: Window size is not remembered

note.body:
It is reproducible by Console 47.1

Steps to reproduce

1. Run in the other terminal emulator

```
$ dconf read /org/gnome/Console/last-window-maximised
true
$ dconf read /org/gnome/Console/last-window-size
(610, 406)
$ dconf read /org/gnome/Console/restore-window-size
$ kgx
```

It opens as expected, full screen.

2. Run in the opened kgx window

```
$ dconf read /org/gnome/Console/last-window-maximised
true
$ dconf read /org/gnome/Console/last-window-size
(610, 406)
$ dconf read /org/gnome/Console/restore-window-size
$ kgx
```

Second window and subsequent ones opens not maximized, in my case in size 54×15 characters.

Read Only – Command exited when trying to close Console opened with command

note.body:
While not wanting this to sound like the terminal emulator equivalent of rage quitting, I am completing the migration of my various Linux platform desktops from Console to [Ptyxis](https://gitlab.gnome.org/chergert/ptyxis), currently with a mix of native package (the default in Fedora Workstation GNOME) or [Flatpak](https://flathub.org/apps/app.devsuite.Ptyxis) (the author's preferred package).

In addition to closing tabs and windows as expected, it has a lot of nice options and very friendly configuration.

Tip: set transparency with `dconf write /org/gnome/Ptyxis/Profiles/<tab>/opacity 0.95` where the tab will expand the profile id.

target_title: Do not set AdwStyleManager:theme from KgxApplication.init

note.body: Just delaying `adw_style_manager_get_default()` to the `GApplicationClass.startup` isn't enough, because `KgxSettings` *also* calls `adw_style_manager_get_default()` inside its own instance initialisation function. The code needs some rejigging.

target_title: data: Replace X-GNOME-Utilities category with generic Utility

note.body:
@ZanderBrown I have converted the MR back to the original one. Please see [this comment](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/merge_requests/3537#note_2269614) and the follow-up one.

Also, the gnome-shell part of the `X-GNOME-Utilities` category is getting removed so it most likely would be useless anyway.

target_title: data: Replace X-GNOME-Utilities category with generic Utility

note.body:
I think so, but I am not sure. You can try asking [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/-/merge_requests/3537). However, as far as I know, if there is a `X-GNOME-Utilities` category in the app desktop file and it is a core GNOME app, it should also be in that list. And old GNOME Terminal actually was there before it got replaced by Console.

And it probably is a good idea to hide Console in the Utilities folder by default since this app is not intended for regular users. It definitely makes more sense than hiding Loupe (Image Viewer) there. :-)

Read Only – Command exited when trying to close Console opened with command

note.body: it's also confusing to more technical users simply by being weird behavior

target_title: Read Only – Command exited when trying to close Console opened with command

note.body: You can simplify this by simply killing the parent of the script via `kill $PPID`. Note that this also closes all kgx windows, but also works with Arch Linux Updates Indicator :)

target_title: Read Only – Command exited when trying to close Console opened with command

note.body:
I had this problem with the "Archlinux Updates indicator" gnome extension, on Wayland, thanks to [this script](https://github.com/NastyaGrifon/WaylandReaper) I installed this [gnome extension](https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/4974/window-calls-extended/) and managed to close the terminal with the following command:


`kill  eval $(gdbus call --session --dest org.gnome.Shell --object-path /org/gnome/Shell/Extensions/WindowsExt --method org.gnome.Shell.Extensions.WindowsExt.FocusPID | awk -F"'" '{print $2}')`


at the end of the update command.

Unfortunately this kill every 'kgx' window but it's not a problem for me because I run it only when updating the system from the tray icon and anything else is open.  

Complete update command (with yay):

`kgx -- /bin/sh -c "yay -Syu --noconfirm ; echo Done - Press enter to exit; read; kill  eval $(gdbus call --session --dest org.gnome.Shell --object-path /org/gnome/Shell/Extensions/WindowsExt --method org.gnome.Shell.Extensions.WindowsExt.FocusPID | awk -F"'" '{print $2}')" `

target_title: Console 46 occasionally becomes unresponsive

note.body:
For a while I ran kgx with `G_MESSAGES_DEBUG=all` but there was nothing visible in the journal when it hung.

This time it happened when I closed one of the open kgx windows and I remembered to attach a debugger to the now stuck process. To me it looks like there is a deadlock when destroying the window.

target_title: Enter in the Find box does not cycle through matches but in ptyxis it does

note.body:
Thanks for looking into this!

> I'm not sure whether it's not supposed to be in Console and only supposed to be in ptyxis just because ptyxis is supposed to have more features in it and Console is supposed to be more lightweight

I understand your worry here, but enter also jumps to the next result in other Gnome apps (like the Text Editor or Papers), so I don't think this is out of scope.

target_title: Default Dead Key Behavior not Being Used?
The console crashes while copying text from it.

note.body:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libnotify/-/issues/41

Also, may I ask who is currently the maintainer of libnotify? There is a bug that has existed for a long time.

target_title: The console crashes while copying text from it.

note.body: If this problem still exists in Gnome 47, I will try to obtain the stack trace. I haven't done it yet, so it may not be easy for me.

target_title: Status line duplication
Status line duplication

note.body: Thank you for answering, and sorry for the false report.

target_title: Status line duplication

note.body: See https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-terminal/-/issues/7998.
